items.title: Calgary man guilty of terrorism offences for fighting with ISIS in Syria
items.summary_auto: Jamal Borhot, who travelled to Syria with his cousin more than 12 years ago, has been found guilty of terrorism offences after a judge ruled that the evidence shows he was fighting for ISIS.

items.title: Flooding recovery efforts underway in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Thailand as death toll tops 1,000
Any Canadian who asks for HIV prevention drugs should get them, doctors say
items.summary_auto: For the first time since 2017, Canadian doctors have released updated clinical guidelines for antiretroviral medications used to prevent HIV.

items.title: Northern Ontario steel mill issues layoff notices to 1,000 workers
Polytechnique expands scholarship program to 14 women in memory of 1989 tragedy
items.summary_auto: Polytechnique Montréal is expanding its scholarship program honouring the 14 women who were killed at the engineering school 36 years ago.

items.title: 'Forever Canadian' petition verified as successful by Elections Alberta
items.summary_auto: A citizen initiative petition to make it official policy for Alberta to stay in Canada has been verified as successful by Elections Alberta.

items.title: Another son of 'El Chapo' pleads guilty to U.S. drug trafficking charges
items.summary_auto: A son of notorious Mexican drug kingpin "El Chapo" pleaded guilty Monday to U.S. drug trafficking charges, months after his brother entered a plea deal.

items.title: Cal Foote, acquitted in Hockey Canada sexual assault case, signs with AHL Wolves
items.summary_auto: Cal Foote has signed an American Hockey League contract with the Chicago Wolves, making him the fourth of five players acquitted of sexual assault in the high-profile trial of members of Canada's 2018 world junior hockey team to continue his career.

items.title: 'Outpouring of kindness' for Ottawa Charge head coach after breast cancer diagnosis
items.summary_auto: Carla MacLeod has been diagnosed with breast cancer, but the overwhelming and positive response to the announcement is giving the Ottawa Charge’s head coach confidence in her fight.

items.title: Inuvialuk designer looks back proudly on Project Runway Canada experience
items.summary_auto: Inuvialuk designer Taalrumiq says her time on Project Runway Canada was a "career highlight" and an opportunity to showcase some of her culture.

items.title: Nor'easter to bring snow, rain and wind to the Maritimes starting Tuesday evening
items.summary_auto: CBC meteorologist Ryan Snoddon says people should prepare for potential power outages and ferry and bridge delays or closures as wind gusts reach 70-90 km/h.

items.title: Carney brings Trudeau-era minister back into cabinet, adds responsibilities to 2 others
items.summary_auto: Marc Miller is the new minister of Canadian identity and culture, as well as official languages.

items.title: All Manitoba schools ordered to review safety measures after student grabbed by sex offender
items.summary_auto: Every school in Manitoba must undertake a safety review and send the assessment to the province's Department of Education, the provincial government says, responding to a child being assaulted last week.

items.title: Manitoba schools ordered to review safety measures after student grabbed by sex offender
items.summary_auto: Every school in Manitoba must undertake a safety review and send the assessment to the province's Department of Education, the provincial government says, responding to a child being assaulted last week.

items.title: Death toll from floods in Indonesia, Sri Lanka and Thailand passes 1,000, with hundreds missing
Canadian injured in West Bank settler attack says they were beaten, passports were stolen
items.summary_auto: A Canadian activist injured in a settler attack over the weekend in a village in the Israeli-occupied West Bank says she and three others were thrown on the ground and beaten by settlers before some of their wallets and passports were stolen.

items.title: Algoma Steel issues layoff notices to 1,000 workers
items.summary_auto: Algoma Steel says it has issued 1,000 layoff notices to workers at its plant in Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

items.title: B.C. bitcoin mines are transitioning into AI data centres
items.summary_auto: Iren, the company behind major data centres in northern B.C. is converting its infrastructure from bitcoin mining into AI storage. The Australia-based company is upgrading equipment at its sites in Prince George, Mackenzie and Canal Flats sites.

items.title: WHO conditionally recommends GLP-1 drugs for obesity
items.summary_auto: The first conditional recommendation by the organization advises the use of GLP-1 drugs by adults, except pregnant women, for long-term obesity treatment, while the second suggests interventions like a healthy diet and physical activity to be offered alongside the medicines.

items.title: 'Rage bait' is the Oxford University Press word of the year, because apparently anger fuels us
items.summary_auto: Oxford University Press has named “rage bait’’ as its word of the year, capturing the internet zeitgeist of 2025.

items.title: Crown Royal plant closure now a done deal, union says
items.summary_auto: "They had made their mind up and they were not changing it," says the head of the union.

items.title: Trump promise to pardon ex-Honduran president convicted of drug trafficking looms as country votes
items.summary_auto: Two conservative challengers were practically tied for the lead in Honduras's presidential contest, with votes from about 55 per cent of polling places counted early Monday, according to preliminary and partial results.

items.title: Calgary recertified as 'bird friendly city' for supporting local and migratory birds
items.summary_auto: Calgary's efforts to support local and migratory bird populations have earned it a recertification by Nature Canada as a bird friendly city, making it the first city to receive the distinction three times.

items.title: Homeowner says she’s out $381K after hiring Ottawa contractor to renovate kitchen
Hong Kong highrise netting did not meet code, officials say, with death toll at 151 people
items.summary_auto: Hong Kong officials said Monday that their investigation into a deadly blaze that killed at least 151 people has revealed some of the netting that covered scaffolding used in renovations was not up to fire-safety codes, as a wave of public sympathy and support was met by government moves to stifle criticism.

items.title: Is there room for separatists and Danielle Smith in the same UCP tent?
items.summary_auto: The premier goes pro-Ottawa as base moves in opposite direction. But she also scored some points at her party's annual meeting.

items.title: ‘It doesn’t discriminate’: Majority of Sudbury overdose deaths occurring behind closed doors
items.summary_auto: A report from Public Health Sudbury and Districts shows that most fatal drug poisonings in the region are happening inside people’s homes — not downtown, in encampments or in public spaces.

items.title: Breath samples collected by drone hold clues to health of North Atlantic right whales
items.summary_auto: A newly published study shows the bacteria in the spray from the whales' blowholes can indicate how healthy the individual is.

items.title: American podiatrist leaving Nova Scotia over bureaucratic frustrations
items.summary_auto: A U.S. podiatrist says he is leaving the province because his patients have to wait years to see a surgeon for procedures on their feet, even though he's trained to do the procedures in his clinic.

items.title: All of Toronto's speed cameras are gone. How did we get to this point?
items.summary_auto: Toronto's speed cameras may be gone, but this time there are no mysterious vandals wielding power tools, no blurry suspect photos and no police investigation.

items.title: Montreal-area paramedics have a new dispatch system. They fear it's putting patients at risk
items.summary_auto: CBC News spoke with five paramedics who say they’ve been sent out to respond to 911 calls unnecessarily — either because the call had already been handled by another team and reappeared in the system, or because several ambulances were dispatched to the same call. Urgences-santé, meanwhile, insists there’s been no impact on patient care since the system was implemented.

items.title: WestJet and Air Transat passengers fight back after airlines falsely claim they can’t film disputes
items.summary_auto: Jason Huang says a WestJet employee grabbed his phone and threatened to deny him boarding when he began recording his conversation during airport check-in. Legal expert say passengers are within their rights to record these interactions, and video and audio recordings may help in battles for compensation.

items.title: Why excavators may be a tool of choice for some cash-seeking thieves
items.summary_auto: This unique form of theft has been happening all over the Greater Toronto Area and beyond. Thieves on the hunt for cash break through the walls of banks using excavators that experts say anyone capable of ordering a key online can drive off the lot.

items.title: Pay high duties or lose U.S. shoppers? Some Canadian retailers forced to choose amid holiday sales
items.summary_auto: Months after the U.S. ended duty-free shipping on small packages, Canadian online retailers will have to make a tough gamble: pay pricey fees on low-value shipments, or get a holiday sales boost from American customers?
